In honor of President Johnson signing Medicare into law on this day in 1965, let's reaffirm our commitment and ensure all Americans have comprehensive health care. I was proud to lay out my #MedicareforAll plan this week so we can ensure everyone has access to the care they need.

Your stories have helped me develop my Medicare for All plan. Nothing is more personal than your health care.

Share your health care story here and we'll highlight some throughout the week. https://t.co/jbSxhzqu0d https://t.co/XVQAZBsrbT

When I’m president, the middle class and working Americans will not bear the brunt of the burden of paying for Medicare for All. It’s time we ask those at the very top and on Wall Street to start contributing more to America’s health.

Right now, the U.S. spends $3.5 trillion a year on health care. 

If we do nothing over the next decade, that number will skyrocket to an estimated $6 trillion. 

We can’t afford the status quo. That’s why I’ve proposed my Medicare for All plan.

Today would have been Emmett Till’s 78th birthday. Yet his life was cut short when he was just 14. Lynching is still not considered a federal hate crime to this day. I have a bill to make it one. It's time we confronted this dark part of our nation's history and right this wrong.

The federal minimum wage:
April 1, 1990: $3.80
April 1, 1991: $4.25
October 1, 1996: $4.75 
September 1, 1997: $5.15 
July 24, 2007: $5.85 
July 24, 2008: $6.55 
July 24, 2009: $7.25 

Ten years later & the federal minimum wage hasn't moved from $7.25. This is why I #FightFor15.
